column5: RCBD: randomized complete block design; RCBDsplit: randomized complete block design with a one-way split plot; splitplot: a non-randomized design with a one-way split plot; RCBDsplitsplitplot: randomized complete block design with a two-way split plot treatment

column6: Derived from location coordinates using the CGIAR-CSI Global-Aridity and Global-PET databases (Zomer et al. 2008)

column6: Percentage of soil that is organic matter (versus mineral) on a weight basis

column6: Soil type based on texture make-up of soil (sand, silt, clay)

Spring: January-June; Summer: June-September; Fall : September – December

Classification of the weed measured as dictated by its growth habit in the US Midwest
column11: The length of time in years to complete one full rotation.
column12: This was calculated from the 'soil's' perspective, as how much time elapses between patterns of crops. For example a wheat-maize-wheat rotation would have a rotation length of 2 years.

column4: Austrian winter pea, barley, berseem clover, canola, cereal rye, ceral rye + hairy vetch, crimson clover, hairy vetch, italian ryegrass, mogul medic, oilseed radish, radish, red clover, rye, rye + vetch, rye grass, santiago medic, triticale, vetch, wheat, winter oat, winter wheat, winter wheat + Austrian winter pea
column5: Cover crop species as reported in study
column6: Cover crop species as reported in the study, often Latin names were not provided so the exact wording of the species common name was maintained; simplification of species categories were used to create the cc_type column
column8: number of crop species in rotation
column11: The number of unique crop species present in the rotation.
column12: Note this includes cover crop species if they were present in the rotation. For diverse mixtures of cover crops/pasture we counted it as one species unit, as we felt it was unfair to infalte the species richness calculations based on functionally similar species being grown together as a unit.

column6: cc_spec column value was used to assign each study to one of the four general groupings of cover crop types
column11: Coefficient of variation in number of months between planting events in one complete rotation cycle.
column12: The number of months between planting events for one complete rotation cycle was extracted. The standard deviation and mean value were calculated. The coefficient of variation (CV) of months between plantings was calculated for each rotation.

column2: cover crop planting month three letter abbrevitation
column5: cover crop planting month three letter abbrevitation
column6: Three letter abbreviation of month
column11: The age of the study at the time of reported measurements
column12: The year of experimental establishment is set as year 0, and each subsequent year adds 1 to this value. If more than one crop is grown during a year this value may be a fraction. If the values were averaged over many years then this represents the average study age, and may therefore be a fraction.

column6: Month
column12: This is the total weed biomass and gives no information about the composition of the weeds that were measured. All values were converted to grams per square meter, regardless of how they were originally reported. NA indicates this study did not report weed biomass.

column6: Day of month
column8: standard error of weed biomass value
column10: positive numeric; blank space indicates value was not reported
column11: Standard error of the weed biomass value recorded.
column12: This value was recorded only if the authors reported it in the manuscript.

column6: Weight of cover crop seeds planted per hectare of land
column12: This is the total number of weeds and gives no information about the composition of the weeds that were measured. All values were converted to plants per square meter, regardless of how they were originally reported. NA indicates this study did not report weed density.

column6: Broadcast refers to seed being scattered (by hand or mechanically) on the surface of the soil with no precise placement of seed; drilled refers to seed being mechanically placed in the soil at a desired depth in a pre-determined pattern
column8: standard error of weed density value
column11: Standard error of the weed density value recorded.
column12: This value was recorded only if the authors reported it in the manuscript.

column4: herbicide, herbicide 1x, herbicide 2x, herbicide 1x + mowing, mowing, none, roller crimper, winter kill
column6: herbicide: an undefined number of sprays with herbicide(s); herbicide 1x: one herbicide spraying event; herbicide 2x: two herbicide spraying events; herbicide 1x + mowing: one herbicide spraying event and one mowing event in any order; mowing: one mowing event; none: cover crop was not terminated; roller crimper: a roller-crimper machine was used; winter kill: the cover crop was selected such that it would die over the winter

cc_termmeth value was used to assign each study to one of the five general groupings of termination method; D: dual (more than one method utilized); H: only herbicide used; M: only mechanical means used; W: winter kill; none: no method was used to terminate the cover crop
